objects.name: xHunt Campaign Using Backdoors for C2
objects.description:
# Summary

Active since at least July 2018, the xHunt campaign has been seen targeting the Kuwaiti government as well as shipping and transportation organizations. Palo Alto's Unit 42 provides insight into new techniques seen with this activity.

# Threat Type

- Malware, Backdoor, DNS Tunneling

# Overview

The xHunt Campaign has been actively observed since at least July 2018. In the latest developments, Unit 42 has uncovered new techniques being employed to provide new C2 vectors. The campaign has focused its efforts mainly on the Kuwaiti government as well as the shipping and transportation industries. The latest information suggests the threat actors have compromised a Microsoft Exchange server on or before August 22, 2019. Analysts note two backdoors, called TriFive and Snugy by Unit 42, as well as a web shell called BumbleBee were discovered. The backdoors are PowerShell scripts that provide the threat actors with backdoor access through the compromised Exchange server. This access provides different C2 channels with which the actors communicate. TriFive is a backdoor that utilizes an email-based channel using Exchange Web Services to create draft emails in the Deleted Items folder of the email account previously compromised. Snugy uses DNS tunneling to run commands on the compromised server. In September 2020, analysts were notified of a breached organization in Kuwait. Suspicious commands were noted as coming from Exchange server through an Internet Information Services (IIS) process. Threat actors then issued commands using BumbleBee, which had been previously installed on the Exchange server. In reviewing the logs, the analysts were unable to find an infection vector. They were able to find two scheduled tasks, which were in place prior to the dates of the collected logs. These tasks executed PowerShell scripts, and although the analysts were unable to confirm, they believe the threat actors were able to access the server prior the creation of logging events. The naming of logs was done in order to blend into other tasks and had names that, upon first glance, would appear to be normal functions. The threat actors were able to resolve hosts through these two scripts. The backdoors mentioned were executed at intervals not matching each other with TriFive occurring every 5 minutes and Snugy every 30 minutes. The hypothesis is that this is done to offer some form of stealth in order to avoid detection. The actor created a draft email with a specific subject that included the commands encrypted and encoded using a base64 format. The commands are executed when PowerShell is directed to the Deleted Items folder and searches for the aforementioned subject line. Persistence for this module is achieved via the scheduled task and not through a looping process. Snugy is a PowerShell backdoor. This backdoor allows the actor to run commands as well as obtain the system's hostname. Snugy is a variant of the CASHY200 backdoor previously employed. Significant overlap exists to suggest this claim. Snugy uses DNS tunneling to communicate with C2 servers using A record lookups to resolve custom subdomains of C2 domains controlled by the actor. Snugy extracts the IP address prior to sending ICMP requests should that technique fail. The tunneling protocol only sends one byte of data per query. This speed makes the backdoor inefficient for the exfiltration of data. DNS tunneling allows for the receipt of four bytes of data making it a little more efficient. Further details of the TTPs of the actor and these tools can be found in the report located within the reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

- A complete list of IoCs can be found in the Reports section to the right.

# Recommendations

- Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
- Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
- Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
- Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
- Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.

# Reference

- https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/xhunt-campaign-backdoors[/](https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/xhunt-campaign-backdoors/)
